post:
Emmett, Jesus was not a rabbi in the classical sense of the term, only in the broad sense, meaning a “teacher”. Jeremiah was also single. A close reading of the gospels reveals that Jesus believed that what he taught was above Torah. Paul took the point further. Benedict XVI and Rabbi Jacob Neusner have discussed this.
The fashion now is science by documentary and history through sensationalism. If one takes Simcha seriously then there will be nothing left to believe in the Bible:
https://www.academia.edu/7471223/Jesus_was_not_buried_in_Talpiot_-_Part_III
He is not an archaeologist, his investigation is agenda-based and filled with distortions, and this applies to the so-called Jesus family tomb, debunked above, the nails in Caiphas(? – the reading is contested),bride of God and the rest.
Professor James Charlesworth fell into his trap, then made his way out, realising the mistake he had made. He has also laid other traps and one famous paleographer was caught in one of them and also made his way out.

title: Science Channel’s new Biblical Conspiracies series
post:
It is not a gospel and it is not lost. It is a sixth century AD pseudepigraphal document in Syriac entitled “Joseph and Aseneth” and all Jacobovici did was to read (twist) it allegorically to read “Jesus and Mary Magdalene”. There is an English translation by David Cook, however is it worth consulting it? It will add nothing, top scholars have dismissed everything in this book, which is a kind of follow up of the “Da Vinci Code”. To see how material has been unscrupulously twisted in this long story, read what top archaeologists (Amos Kloner) and biblical scholars (Father Joseph A. Fitzmyer and François Bovon) have said:
https://www.academia.edu/7556467/Jesus_was_not_buried_in_Talpiot_-_Parts_I_and_II
The link to Part III is above,and Part IV should be written in the beginning of next year.

It seems that it has not been understood that that the producer of the documentary believes that the “one book” is “by God himself”. It also depends on which parts of “the one book” he considers to have come “from God himself”.
Suffice it to say now that the nails are shorter in length than typical Roman crucifixion nails, it is not proved that it came from Caiaphas’ tomb, there is no certainty that it is the high priest’s tomb, and, above all,there is no DNA material on the nails, as alleged.
The producer also takes anyone who contradicts his “findings” to court, particularly when it means that there will be less money in the pocket:
